Award.AwardTitle: African American Workforce Development in Physics and Astronomy: A Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Southern California will conduct a workshop to identify and address issues that impact career pathways for African American students in physics and astronomy. Diverse experts from Pk-12, higher education, industry, and professional societies will convene to (1) identify evidence-based approaches to mitigating barriers to African American students? academic performance and workforce participation, (2) discuss strategies for more rigorous, third-party evaluations of programs or activities designed to increase the representation of African Americans in physics and astronomy, and (3) propose research topics focused specifically on underrepresentation in the physics and astronomy workforce. The two-day workshop coincide with the annual meeting of the National Society of Black Physicists and will employ a ?strengths-based, pathway model? approach to discuss an action-oriented, systematic, data-driven strategy to broaden the participation of African Americans in physics and astronomy. The workshop will result in knowledge that can be used by various stakeholder communities, including community colleges, to design effective interventions to reverse the negative trends in physics and astronomy. It also will catalyze collaborations to implement innovations to broaden participation in those disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this workshop was to engage 20-25 diverse stakeholders/experts with a range of expertise in the experiences of Blacks in PK-12, higher education, and academic and industry careers specific to the physical sciences. The workshop used a 'strengths-based, pathway' approach to devise data-driven, action plans on the systemic, institutional, and individual levels at critical junctures on the physical science career pathway. With the direct support from the National Society of Black Physicists, we invited participants from institutions that have exhibited promising practices resulting in the enhancement of African American participation in physical science education and the workforce.

Workshop participants were assembled into sub-teams, which included experts from four areas: Pre-college transition; college; graduate school; and the workforce. Each group was comprised of at least one member from each of the various stakeholder categories to provide a more comprehensive approach to the discussion. Additional goals were to (1) Identify evidence-based approaches, strategies, and practices to enhance the quality of preparation at each stage along the physics and astronomy pathway, and that foster both race and gender equity; (2) Identify gatekeepers and critical leverage points for effective interventions that enhance academic preparation, performance, and workforce participation; (3) Discuss strategies for third-party evaluations of programs or activities designed to increase the representation of Blacks in physics and astronomy; and (4) Develop a research plan to build a body of knowledge on the participation of Black in physics, astronomy, and the workforce.

The result of a smaller supplemental meeting was to: a) develop a few of the ideas generated in the pre-conference convening; b) determine the feasibility and viability of implementing one or more of the 'big ideas'; and 3) draft an NSF grant proposal to implement and examine the impact of one of the 'big ideas' generated from the pre-conference (see https://socialjustice.usc.edu/research-engagement/reports/ ). These 'big ideas' included mobile physics camps, youth competitions, mentorship experiences, curriculum/ teacher training, theme-weeks at school, and addressing fundamental questions like 'What does it mean to be a Black physicist?' These 'big ideas' are not necessarily transformative ideas, but when the social scientists, physicists, and institutional collaborators agree to participate and assist in implementing these 'big ideas' they become transformational.

This pre-conference convening served as a critical lever in developing meaningful and productive interdisciplinary partnerships. Additionally, this convening revealed the need for more collaborative efforts to better support a community and the growth of Black in physics and astronomy.

Our pre-conference team, attendees and speakers were well-posed to engage our pre-conference goals and objectives. Our participants included:

Brian Beckford, Ph.D., Professor of Physics at the New York City College of Technology of the City University of New York.

Reginald Blake, Ph.D., Presidential Postdoctoral Fellow, University of Michigan Physics Department.

Tabbye Chavous, Ph.D., Professor of Education and Psychology, University of Michigan and director of the university?s National Center for Institutional Diversity.

Yanne Chembo, Ph.D., International Commission of Optics (ICO) steering committee for Regional Development until September 2017, and IEEE Photonics Society board in charge of outreach.

Marta Dark McNeese, Ph.D., Associate Professor at Spelman College in the Physics Department.

Earnestine Psalmonds Easter, Ph.D., Program Director in the Division of Graduate Education, National Science Foundation (NSF).  

Terry K. Flennaugh, Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Race, Culture, and Equity in Education, Michigan State University.  

Byron Freelon, Ph.D., Board of directors of the NSBP, faculty in the physics department of the University of Louisville

Anita Gopal, Ph.D., International Officer for the National Postdoctoral Association.

Caesar R. Jackson, Ph.D., Professor of Physics, North Carolina Central University.

Dawn Johnson, Ph.D., Associate Professor and chair of the Higher Education, Syracuse University.

Lauren A. Mecum, Ph.D., Community Outreach & Development Manager, IEEE Photonics Society.
